segments.Text:
This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 Alright, so, hello everybody, I hope you're enjoying your time in this beautiful city.
Thank you for organization, for invitation and everything.
Today we are going to present you our project, Atomic Threat Coverage, which represents technical
implementation and operationalization of threat-centric methodology and Mitre ATT&CK
framework specifically.
At the same time we will present you the reasons which stands behind decision to develop this
project and expected and a few unexpected benefits which we had when we started processing
all information automatically.
So everything I'm going to present, we're going to present to you today is free and
open source, available on GitHub and ready to be implemented in your environment.
Alright, my name is Daniel, I'm working as a threat detection team lead in TIETO SOC
in Czech Republic.
Today we will perform together with Mateusz Wider, he is SOC incident responder in TIETO
SOC in Krakow in Poland.
Also we have two members who unfortunately couldn't participate today, Mikhail Aksionov,
he is SOC automation team lead in Moscow, in Bizon, and Jakob Weinzettel, he is threat
detection specialist in TIETO SOC in Krakow in Poland as well.
At the same time we're all Krakow 26th Congress meetings members, these are our home meetups,
like local meetups I would say.
We used to present first proof of concepts or interesting ideas, updates there first,
so if you guys have been in Krakow, come over and say hi, these meetings take place each
first Friday of the month.
Alright, let me provide you some historical background.
In 2014, when I started, when I moved from networking security to general computer security
and started working with offensive defensive stuff, I had only one question, and also started
working with CM systems specifically, I had only one question, where all of these people
get correlation rules.
And I couldn't find the answer, the thing is that at that time, basically if you're
looking for like correlation rules, detection rules, methodology, anything, you can only
find like information about brute force and everybody was like, you know, buy our CM system
for a couple of millions of dollars and you will be able to detect brute force.
Alright, maybe something else.
Basically I started also doing some hacking stuff, offensive, and I was able to intrude
into system, move laterally, dump credentials and everything, but I couldn't find any information
about detection.
Like literally, you know, empty field, silence, no articles, no methodology, nothing.
And for me it was clear that to detect something or to defend the system from something, you
need to understand this something, right?
Like how the adversaries operate, how it looks like, what kind of tools they use and what
is their motivation.
And I couldn't find the answer for these questions, like why nobody is doing that?
Why it's so obvious, but not so popular?
And I was digging into the topic, like looking for something which would reflect my own understanding
of this area and I found one.
It's called Intelligent Defense, developed by Lockheed Martin Corporation in 2012.
And the main idea behind it is you're supposed to know your enemy.
It is basic for military, but not so popular.
At least it wasn't that popular that time, basically just five years ago.
So I grabbed it, started digging into what interesting is there, what can I use?
And, you know, after just one year, in 2015, Mitra released their framework called Mitra
attack.
How many of you guys use Mitra attack framework in your daily job?
Can you please raise your hand?
Great.
That's just awesome.
Thank you.
So I don't, for those who are not using or not familiar, I will provide just simple description.
It's just basically adversary model.
Description of steps, techniques, procedures and tools they, adversaries, use during the
intrusion and post exploitation activities in other environment.
Probably most of you familiar with concept of cyber kill chain, also known as cyber attack
life cycle in Mitra paradigm.
Basically what they did.
They just split it into two pieces, pre attack and enterprise attack.
Which is about delivery exploitation and all post exploitation activities which adversaries
do.
And basically that's how it looks like.
It is a table.
There are 12 columns which represents tactics.
Tactic is tactical objective of an adversary during the intrusion.
And there are more than 200 cells which represents techniques, which are like exact way how to
achieve this tactical objective.
For example, exfiltration over alternative protocol, it is a technique.
At the same time it is a way how to achieve tactical goal, which is exfiltration.
There is a simple description of what is it about, mitigation detection strategies, example
of use in the wild and some references.
So basically each technique has such description.
So and with all of this stuff, like all of the mindset, we of course decided to start
implementing it.
And we faced a few problems during the operationalization.
First of all, description for Mitra itself is too high level.
It's not actionable.
Which means that you cannot just pick up this advices about detections, mitigations and
go and implement it in your environment.
To actually implement it, you need to be more specific for yourself.
Understand what you are doing and why.
At the same time, it's always a team work.
So you need to explain your team members, other departments, leadership, what you are
doing, why you are doing this and everything else.
So it needs to be like detailed to be operationalized.
Another thing is, which is falling from the first topic, is that Mitra at Agbar itself
doesn't provide you with the ability to explain what exactly do you need and doesn't provide
you with the arguments, like proofs, what exactly, why exactly you need this one.
The good example of such thing is CIS one lock source.
When you are saying to your CMT, hey, guys, I want to have CIS one in our detection engine.
Because I heard that you can detect lots of things with that.
And they're asking you, all right, how many data, what will be increased in our EPS?
What exactly you need to install there?
And why don't you like the default, like, you know, Windows event lock, like, application
security and system channels?
And it is relatively simple question.
But to answer it and to be understood by everybody, you have to do, like, huge research, like,
what exactly you can detect with CIS one, why it is better than Windows event lock,
how many data, like, you will have after that, and what can you detect?
Many things.
So each kind of each time somebody is asking you to prove something, to explain yourself,
you have to do lots of things to provide these proofs and compelling arguments.
And last thing, well, basically there are lots of things, but these are main for us.
Reporting leadership.
Basically, when you are starting the implementation, leadership want to know how you're progressing,
what is the roadmap, what is the current status?
And where you will be, like, in two months for each and every customer.
Because we are MSS, we're supposed to do reporting per customer.
And it is also something which is supposed to be simple.
But any time you're preparing the report, you have to collect lots of data from multiple
departments, compile it together, provide an understandable way for management.
Which is also kind of challenging.
And that's why in 2016, summer 2016, we decided to create our own tool or our own framework
based on Mitre.
And to basically operationalize this.
And it's called not Mitre, it's called use case framework, yeah.
So you may have heard about it in some conferences in Poland or Luxembourg in 2017 or 18.
If you haven't, don't worry.
Today we will present you the same benefits and something even more actual.
So basically, what was it?
It was a confluence knowledge base with a listed structure.
We were using Mitre attack technique as a separate use case.
And we were mapping multiple entities to this use case.
Like alerts, related data needed for which required for this alerting.
And related logging policy.
And this way we were expressing ourselves to CM team.
Also mapping their response actions, response playbooks, and many other things.
So Mateusz will tell you more about it in a few minutes.
So basically, we solved the problems I've listed using this tool.
But we got another set of problems.
Good example of it is a unit test.
Unit test is an entity which allow us to trigger some specific detection rule.
And you're putting all of this stuff manually to confluence page.
So basically, just to execute it, you need to go there, copy paste it, and to victim
machine to, you know, trigger something.
And everything was filled manually and maintained manually.
Another example is detection rule.
We were using our own language to describe detection logic for CM team.
We call it high level detection logic.
Well, basically, everything is simple.
At the same time, we were supporting Kibana queries, plan queries, and CM team were doing
their own stuff.
And everything was done manually.
So just imagine if you want to add their new service name, for example.
We have to update this logic, we have to update Kibana query, we have to update other things,
which require quite a lot of time.
That's the simple, let's say, overview of the stuff we had.
This one is a use case.
There you can see, like, biggest square is a use case with a lot of links there that
they needed, logging policies, software, and other stuff.
And everything was tightly connected.
So just imagine, for example, when we were creating data needed entity, there were no
such thing.
We were doing, we were putting this data into logging policy.
And we decided one day, like, hmm, well, it makes sense to separate these things.
And we started working on a new entity, and we had to rebuild basically everything, change
all the links, add new links, create new articles for each data needed, which took, like, two,
three weeks for two specialists, and that's really a lot, and we're not counting the general
maintenance.
Another problem just following from that is that we were deprecating some stuff, but still
there are too many places where you should update it.
We just, you know, we're missing some places, and that's why in some lists we were seeing
these deprecated alerts or deprecated other kind of entities.
So last fall, we reached some horrible number.
If you think it is small, how about that?
So really, guys, when you're maintaining such amount of analytics manually in web-based
engine, it became a madness.
That's why last fall we decided to change.
And we were inspired by two projects.
First is Elastic Command Schema.
We were contributing to it that time, and we were really inspired by the way how they
handled their stuff.
So you basically update one configuration file or add something there, edit it, and
execute make command, and after that, it regenerates all the documentation, all the CSV files,
all the index templates, basically everything for you in the background, like, automatically,
which is just awesome.
Another project is Sigma.
We were using Sigma in the beginning in the first versions of use case framework, but
then we decided to change to our own logic due to some internal reasons.
But last fall, we saw huge community support for this project.
At the same time, they've started mapping their rules to Mitre ATT&CK techniques, and
that's why we decided to try to use them again.
And what's happened then?
Beautiful integrations, automated workflows, big discoveries, and also fun and profit for
us and for community.
And Mateusz will tell you more about it.
Thank you, Daniel.
Hello.
So we've set a few requirements for ourselves.
First of all, we wanted to work with plain text files.
Because they are easier to manage, we could use version control systems like Git and do
some bulk changes inside of those.
We decided to not do any kind of maintenance in web-based editors, because that amount
of work which we did in Confluence was just overwhelming, and we decided to not do that
anymore.
We wanted to minimal manual job to be able to focus on more meaningful work, like developing
new rules or tests, and we wanted to automate everything which was able to be automated.
So following that requirements, first of all, we wanted something to work for us as trigger
entities, and we decided to use Atomic Red Team for that.
If you're not familiar with this project, it uses Atomics, which are tests mapped to
Mateusz's techniques, and might be used for testing detection capabilities and mitigation
systems which are implemented.
So those Atomics are stored in YAML files, and they contain actions which might be executed
by adversaries or Red Team, and what's really cool about this project is that it also comes
with execution frameworks which basically makes all of those tests actionable, so you
can prepare a list of tests which you would like to execute, and quickly execute all of
them in your test environment using those frameworks.
So once we had something to test, we needed to detect such activities.
And for that, we decided to use the Sigma project.
If you're not familiar with it, it is the generic signature format for CM systems, and
the real power of it comes from its converter, which is able to translate rules which are
stored in Sigma format into queries for multiple CM systems like Splunk, Elasticsearch, Kibana,
Greylock, ArcSight, the list of supported systems is quite huge, so that's only some
examples.
And that's how sample rule written in Sigma format looks like.
As you can see, inside the tags, we have mappings to Mitre's techniques and tactics.
There are some references, and the conditions which are necessary to met for the rule to
trigger on some specific event.
So to make those rules work correctly, we have to collect proper data, and to keep track
of it, of what we have to collect, we've created data-needed entities.
So here we have the raw log sample, which you may want to pass to CM team or data engineers
to show them what they should expect.
The list of the fields, redundant ones here are used for the analytic purposes.
Also the provider of that log, some references, and what's most important, it also lists the
logging policies which are needed to be implemented to collect some specific data.
And that's how sample logging policy entity looks like.
So as I said, they describe what have to be configured to collect some data, and at the
same time, they provide exact steps which have to be followed to collect such, to implement
those policies.
And recently, we also created new entity, which is customer, and this one allows you
to track which data you are collecting, which logging policy, and which detection rules
are implemented.
And it's not like this is useful only for the service providers, because for internal
security teams, the customer might be another department, remote office, or even some specific
assets like some server or group of the hosts.
Going further, we've introduced enrichment entities, and those entities describes how
to enrich events with additional information.
So here we have the list of requirements, list of events which might be enriched, and
description of the goal of some specific enrichment.
For example, this might be introduction of new fields, renaming or translation of some
of the existing ones.
And it also contains the configuration which is needed to achieve such enrichment.
Another thing are response actions, and we've created those for incident response teams.
So they contain the workflows associated with specific incident response phases, and we
are using them to construct the response playbooks.
And response playbooks are used as incident response plan for some specific threat, and
they are using response actions as building blocks.
And since those were written in very granular way, it gives ability to use same action inside
multiple playbooks.
So if you will update the response action, all of the playbooks which uses that detection
will be updated as well.
Quite new stuff are visualisations.
So here we are aiming for ability of creation visualisation independently from the systems.
Currently, we are supporting only Kibana, but our next goal is to support Splunk as
well, and in future maybe other systems.
So as you can see, it's just a description of what have to be visualised.
And we are using them to create the dashboards.
So it allows you to create dashboards by just listing the names of visualisation in
which you are interested, and they're supposed to be shareable and easy to maintain.
So a few words what's going on under the hood.
We separated data logic and presentation layers from each other.
All of our entities are stored in that YAML files which I just showed to you, so it's
easy to do some changes inside of them or create new stuff.
For example, if you have some custom logging for application, it shouldn't be a problem
to add them.
We wrote most of the code in Python, and we wrote few modules to present that data in
different formats and calculate some mappings between them, and what's also worth to mention
that we are using the Jinja templates for human-readable wikis, so it's kind of easy
to adjust how you want to present it, and since it's Jinja, it also allows you to create
new export formats, so currently we are supporting only Markdown and Deconfluence, but it shouldn't
be a problem to export that data to other wiki system like media wiki.
And small demo time.
So I would like to show you step by step kind of detailed tutorial how to implement atomic
thread coverage inside your environment.
So it starts from execution of make utility.
And basically that's all.
That's all you have to do.
So what just happened?
All of the submodules which are connected were updated.
In this case, it was the public version of Sigma project and atomic thread, but this
part is configurable, so if you have your own private forks of that projects, you can
configure ATC to use those.
All of the entities were exported to Markdown, to Deconfluence, and additional files with
analytics were created, and Daniel will show you right now how it looks like after that
export and what you can do with the files which were exported.
Thank you.
Thank you, Mateusz.
All right.
Come here.
So, guys, I just want to ask you to follow this QR code, or better if you have a laptop,
better use this short link to open our demonstration.
It's available in public, but for mobile phone it looks horrible.
So better to use laptop.
Basically I'm going to show you how it looks like in Confluence, and, again, just to refresh
the what Mateusz said, everything which we're going to show you right now based on open

actions.
All right.
I hope you've managed to do it.
So, basically, that's how Confluence looks like.
As you can see, the structure similar to use case framework, but a bit different.
So it was created automatically.
Just keep it in mind.
If you open detection rule, you will see this rendered table with all the mappings, clickable

And a few automatically generated queries.

So if you will click to data needed, we will go to this article.

And again, very important thing is logging policies, because data needed just not exist

So basically how it works, you just provide CM team links to the article, or list of links

Let me summarise this stuff.
First of all, we had a few expected pros, which are working with text files, not working

using Bash or Python, or anything we want.
Use Git flow, CI, and everything to, you know, just for general programming or development.

Total automation.
We don't do almost like anything manually, nothing manually.

At the same time, our data is compatible with community projects like Sigma, so basically

I have to speed up, I see.
There are a few unexpected pros.
First of all, visualizations of existing analytics.

So for now, CM team has their own dashboard to track implementation, like they see how

basically everywhere.

At the same time, we will have more interesting ideas, analytics, execution frameworks, and

Another thing is evangelization of MitraTag.
I believe we as a community need more projects with MitraTag taggings, and first example

Just imagine what will happen if we will tag all the post-exploitation modules of Metasploit.
There are basically more than 300 of them.
We will dramatically increase our simulation testing ability.

So if you guys were seeking for a project to do, like next couple of months, or maybe

So you can find us, we can discuss it, maybe provide you with some help, or advice, anything.
You're welcome with that.
